Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a Future Internet Architecture (FIA) principal investigator meeting in June, 2015. This meeting focuses on security within the individual architectures of each project, future systems research topics, and a meeting for students from the various FIA projects to discuss their specific research projects.

Intellectual Merit: The discussion of security issues is intended to summarize and explore security design choices within each of the funded FIA network designs. The results of this workshop should serve to better understand the implications of security issues, and to improve communication and understanding between the design teams.

Broader Impacts: The broader goal of the NSF FIA program is enhancing the relevance and impact of the NSF program of network research, intellectual enrichment of the network research community, and the contribution of new concepts and thought leadership to the future of the Internet. The program, and the workshops in particular, are a means to train a cohort of academic network researchers in the practice of long-range architectural thinking. The program has the potential to contribute to a future Internet that is materially more secure, robust, economically viable, and fit for the needs of society than the Internet of today. The results of this workshop, which will be posted on the FIA website http://www.nets-fia.net/ for public dissemination, will be a contribution to this broader goal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported one in a series of Future Internet Architecture--Next Phase (FIA-NP) principal investigator meetings, this one in June, 2015. This meeting focused on security within the individual architectures of each project, possible future systems research challenges for the NSF community, and a meeting for students from the various FIA projects to discuss their specific research projects. It featured presentations from the four funded projects and an extended discussion about the relationship between network architecture and security.

The key conclusions were that the basic architecture of an Internet does not describe or generate its security properties, but is better thought of as a tool-kit of mechanisms and approaches that can be exploited by the higher layers of the system (different apps, perhaps at different times) to achieve the desired attributes. At the same time, different designs can have important impact on issues such as how vulnerabilities manifest (what mechanisms are centralized or decentralized), the privacy of communication, or how the architecture can evolve to meed changing security challenges.

The broader goal of the NSF FIA program, of which these workshops are a part, is enhancing the relevance and impact of the NSF program of network research, intellectual enrichment of the network research community, and the contribution of new concepts and thought leadership to the future of the Internet. The program, and the workshops in particular, are a means to train a cohort of academic network researchers in the practice of long-range architectural thinking. The program has the potential to contribute to a future Internet that is materially more secure, robust, economically viable, and fit for the needs of society than the Internet of today. The results of this workshop, which will be posted on the FIA website http://www.nets-fia.net/ for public dissemination, will be a contribution to this broader goal.
